This is a criticism of the rendering and color temperature. I like the world design and art style.  

That being said, this game does have some great mechanics, though irksome at times.  Climbing is a lot of fun. The holsters, while seemingly a cool idea a first, quickly become annoying when they swap your weapon loadouts or drop weapons without your consent. It doesn't do a good job at interpreting the user's intent. The hitboxes are quite large, and as the weapons pause in front of you, it is easy to accidently destroy it while trying to use an item stored on your chest. It is just cumbersome and unreliable. It would be nice to be able to turn of the haptics as well. 

After the first hour the game loop gets rather repetitive. The missions seem fine, but collecting alloy and squishing fruit becomes a chore, and something I would rather avoid. I heard good reviews about this game; still I approached Stormland with caution, afraid of getting disappointed. Well, in fact, it has surpassed what I heard. Having played titles Half Life Alyx, TWD Saints and Sinners, I can say that, to me, this game is a masterpiece. Since the beginning, it gradually builds up by allowing you to discover more and more in all aspects and ends up being a blast. I've also found it very refined, starting with the controls.

Edit (11/29/21): a few weeks after writing my review, 
I decided I'd come back and play Stormland, as it had been a while since I played.
Having replayed this game from the start again, I feel like I should re-evaluate my review a bit. I think the first time I played I came in with the wrong idea. 
I was sorta expecting some sort of really big story with a good campaign. 
But the more I was replaying this time, the more I realized that this game is more of a looter shooter with interesting lore, rather than a shooter with a meaty campaign. It's sorta like with Metroid Prime, where the gameplay is forefront, and the story never really gets in the way, but you can dig into it if you really want to. 
And the lore is pretty interesting I gotta say. You won't get it all though in one cycle, so it's one of the motivators to keep playing. The game also wastes zero time getting you into the action, no main menu when you start up, you just load into camp, walk to the pod, and head to the stormland, which takes like roughly 30 seconds total. The gun mechanics while servicable are still quite fun, though I do wish they added more. Though the multiple arms types you can use throughout the game add a fair bit to the combat. The enemy Ai is ok, it's not completely braindead, but it definitely could've been a bit better. Now overall, I still quite enjoy this game, however I still feel like $40 is asking a lot for this game, I'd say $30 is a lot more reasonable, but anything lower than $̴2̴5̴ ($20) would be a steal personally. I'm still incredibly disappointed that nothing more will be done with this game due to Insomniac's acquisition by Sony, so this game or its series will likely never have a future.

If you just bought a quest a week ago stay away from this, because the movement mechanics are quite intense, and avoid especially on low end hardware (I played it on ryzen 5 1600 af 16gb ram and rx580) Although I didnt' experience motion sickness from these things plus repeated framerate drops and intense asynchronous space warping, I've had a couple of years of vr experience. If you do have lower-end stuff like myself but still want to try it out, I recommend you stick to recommended res in the oculus software, and stay on the selected presets when you first boot the game, even if it looks bad. For more advnaced players you can turn off asw in the oculus debug tool, turn on medium model lod and ambient shadows. anything more will cause constant performance problems and will effectively turn your gpu into a toaster.

MAIN ACTIVITY:
Walkathon on islands searching/collecting fruits so you can improve abilities and shooting minerals to craft weapons supplies. Occasionally a gun fight that can easily be won.  
Missions are linear, you are cog and zero influence on the outcome. There are no side quests to obtain better weapons. 
Game respects your time. It loads almost instantly from SSD and drops you into last save without wasting time on main screens. Fortunately no loading screen between died and restarted.

Environment not interactive. Shooting wildlife, plants, rocks etc have zero effects. Everything is static. Although some plants/wildlife can be scanned there’s no reward for doing so. No purpose.
GFX: Gfx was low textured, low resembling 480p video in headset. Ultra on Quest 2 with Link cable and/or Virtual Desktop.  I couldn’t find a solution. On PC screen looked gorgeous. 

GUNS: 
Satisfying, especially the two handed mode or dual wielding. Other than ammo capacity I couldn’t feel any  difference between Level 1 and Level 4 guns. Guns have no weight, firing one handed mode didn’t feel any different in accuracy.
My fave favourite gun was the hand grenade launcher and the carbine. 

STORY: 
although there is one can be ignored because have zero influence on how it turns out. You are basically on a walkathon. 

ABILITY : 
Two most useful are magnetic chassis, another skill increases the amount of metal collection. Once I discovered how to vault I never used the increased jump height ability again. 


Worth $30? No. On Steam this game would have been -75% on many occasions already. games on Oculus doesn’t go for -75% deep discount. 
Spend your money on Half Life Alyx.

When this game released there wasn’t much choice in story based VR games.

I got immersed about 5-10 minutes into play.  

BUGS & Extended Review. 
First the bugs, annoying but not game breaking. Jumping onto rock faces I sometimes blocked bu invisible walls, hands clipping through transparent glass. Most objects are static place holders only, 9/10 crates are low textured static objects. 
Wildlife can’t be shot/killed, bullets pass right through. 
Enemies sometimes can shoot through walls.
When vaulting up a rock guns get dislodged and fall to the ground, then when I went back to recover the weapons disappeared. 
Weapons and objects fall through the surface. Happened many times.
Fruit and metal power ups can be inside walls or below the surface making it impossible to recover.
One can easily disassemble a gun by accident. 
The world is empty. Other than the mission objectives no interaction with any of the plants, electrical or mechanical objects.  Everything is simply a place holder. 
No side quests. Straight linear game despite open world.  
No reason or motivation really to explore, no special weapons to find.
All the islands are basically the same.
Enemies are easy to kill, predictable behaviour and they are virtually blind. It’s easy to sneak up and almost one shot kill them.
Guns feel satisfying, especially the way weapons fold out in two handed mode.
One back gun slot, since there is no weight on guns why only one slot on back? Maybe devs felt you would be too overpowered.

Gfx: Played on Ultra with Quest 2.
Viewed through headset looks like 480p video. Image on PC monitor is pristine beautiful.
Even on Rift CV1 the gfx was terrible low resolution. I couldn’t find a solution.

This game features a Main Campaign that once beaten unlocks a cycling world that resets once a week every tuesday. There is a second story that becomes more difficult if you can beat that story before the cycle ends, and can also lose difficulty if you do not beat it before the end of a cycle. 

I came back to this game after abandoning it to play other games (I had just bought my headset and wanted to try mutliple games out). I am so happy that I decided to give it another go with some quality time to feel out the game. The game has many powerups and abilities that do not take too long to unlock, but also require a solid amount of grinding resources for. They don't make the grinding mechanic feel like it is too quick or too slow. Once you fully upgrade you abilities that influence how you glide and climb in the game you basically become a god that can climb and fly to any place that you can see. 

Combat is a little awkward to get used to but once you get the flow of pulling weapons out and which button combinations use your special abilities you go from being a little awkward to becoming a one man army nothing can stop.  AI is pretty basic, which makes lower difficulties boring once you have mastered them. I like to play games like this as stealthily as possible. Sometimes there are scenarios where you really do need to plan out your route, other times the AI is blind and you just need to either keep distance or wait for them to turn around. 

Why I recommend this game: The movement mechanics are exactly what I want as a VR experience. Climbing, flying, and "surfing" is amazing in this game and feeling like a robot god is pretty cool. 

#1 thing devs could work on: "Beating" the game/cycle is extremely dissapointing. Nothing really happens besides a cinematic scene as you fly away to let you know you beat the main mission. I thought I didn't beat it at first until I watched a walkthrough on Youtube afterward to make sure.  Other than that, no complaints.

review_title: Overall, a really, really great game
one_reviews_text: Playing on Quest 2.  If you're new to VR and are looking for a more console-like RPG/scifi experience, Stormland is a GREAT game to start with.  Same studio responsible for Ratchet and Clank, and you can tell.  The story is well-done and interesting without being overly kiddish, dramatic or complex.  There's plenty of campaign content to play through - not hitting many of the side quests and activities, it still took me about 12 hours to finish - and even when you're done, there's still plenty of stuff to do around the world just to enjoy the mechanics.  Which, by the way, are really solid.  Movement in this game - espeically the climbing, gliding and flying - works really well but can be disorienting to VR newbies.  There are some occasional glitches when picking things up, but it's never bad enough to really interfere with the experience.  Lots of modularity to your character's loadout and setup, though a few more guns would be nice.  It's a fantastic game and my personal favorite in VR so far.  I'd love to see a sequel or DLC produced more recently with expanded content and additonal abilities and locations.  Well worth the money!

The islands mostly look the same though (there's only 1 biome basically) and the only thing that really changes is your abilities and the strength of the enemies that you face. You can visit them in any order you like, but there's really no reason to go to one if you're not being sent there as part of the current campaign mission.

So in a nutshell, it's fun, with some really innovative abilities (by the end of it you're basically flying around like a super hero), but hasn't got much replay value after you've experienced everything the game has to offer.

I feel like I got my money's worth out of it, but am in no rush to pick it back up again.

review_title: The New VR Reference since Lone Echo!
one_reviews_text:
Tested using i7 7700K processor, oc'ed GTX 1080, 16GB ram and Rift CV1. 

At first I cranked everything up to Ultra and it didn't work very well, a lot of stuttering - but then I reduced every setting to the lowest and started to check each setting individually. Turns out that I can set nearly everything to Ultra, but real time shadows must be deactivated - and temporal antialiasing must be used for the CV1 for best performance and image quality. Note that I'm forcing super sampling (ss) 2.0 using Oculus Tray Tool (OTT). When using OTT, OTT totally overrides the in-game res scale. I checked using the OTT Pixel Density HUD that ss was indeed 2.0. 

Optimal setting for GTX 1080 (Ti) using CV1 may be:
1. Deactivate real-time shadows (you still get nice shadows, maybe real-time shadows are for the RTX 2080/3060 Ti...).
2. Set everything to Ultra. 
3. Make sure to use temporal antialiasing (SMAA is probably the optimal choice for lcd HMDs, but may increase gpu burden more than temporal). 

- and then I stepped into the most amazing VR world I've ever seen. I've only played a couple of hours, but for now this doesn't feel like a 10/10 game to me - feels more like 14/10, lol - especially compared to other games I've rated 5/5. I really think - for now - that Stormland goes way beyond the normal rating scale, because this game truly feels like the new VR reference. The game is completely smooth on my system, but it's not solid 90 fps, although I do get 90 fps occasionally. 
Stormland totally looks like a "system seller" to me. The amount of detail added to this game is breathtaking. 
Not sure I could ask for more - this feels like the VR game of my dreams. I love sci-fi much more than Vikings. Maybe I should write a big thank you note to Zuckerberg, but he's probably busy playing the game, lol. I haven't been as excited for any VR game since Lone Echo.

review_title: It was GREAT, now it's BROKEN!

Now, as soon as you move your head in any direction to look around, your arms/hands somehow weirdly jitter and move in the complete opposite direction, then they abruptly snap back in place to match your real hands when you stop doing that. You basically feel like you have zero control of what your hands are doing while moving your head. It messes up your weapon aiming, the orientation of your shield (so imagine either shooting at or blocking an enemy and as soon as you turn your head to look at your surroundings you either miss your target or get hit by its attacks even though your hands remained in place in real life), pretty much everything you're doing with your hands and it just looks BAD. It was NOT like this at launch so any claims about this being because of the inverse kinematics and how the game is supposed to behave are simply WRONG. I submitted a report once months ago but nothing has been done since. I'm using the original Oculus Rift with three trackers, I don't know if it's like this on the S too but either way, it used to work properly, now it doesn't and makes the game so annoying it's unplayable even though you can technically mind how you move around, rely more on the analog stick to turn around than your head (so what's the point of 360 VR then) and still complete it. *EDIT/UPDATE*
After playing about 6 hours now I'm extremly pleased with the game. One of the cleanest and most beautiful VR games I've had the pleasure of playing. I have two issues however. 

PROS
-Great graphics
-Great moving mechanics
-Good story
-Enjoyable gameplay 
-Variety of upgrades and weapons

CONS
-Sniper rifles are pretty useless as the zoom function, although looks neat, does not zoom in much at all and when it does there is no reticle with which to aim. Major let down for me cause the game could really take advantage of the landscape with good sniping. 
-AI is pretty braindead. For the most part you can bum rush a group of 2 or 3 with a minigun with minimal worry. Turret defenses are a different story. Couldn't find a difficulty toggle to increase enemies or AI pressure. 
-Possibly short. I haven't finished the main story as I like to explore everything. And if you do too then you'll have plenty to explore. But I think that the end is coming soon as the storyline seems to be hinting at a final boss style fight. This last one is complete speculation.

review_title: The best VR game to date

What i like about the game, well... i enjoy the climbing and the surfing or whatever. jetpack is nice too. i'm not too fond of the guns, so i mostly use the laser you start with. the guns sight is a red dot which is hard to see sometimes, so i don't really use the weapons much right now. i feel the game is fun but will get repetitive fast, though it's a fun vr game so far, ive got a few hours played so far. the upgrades are nice, n i love that we get more and more new abilities for the robot we play as. 

i like the scanner you get which makes it easy to find minerals and enemies also, i keep using it almost all the time. 

the graphics are good, but i feel like it would be better if i had a better gpu maybe, but looks nice enough. the biggest problem i noticed while playing was that my knees started hurting a bit, since you don't crouch often, and stand still most of the time, it can make you very stiff in the knees. this isn't the only game with that issue, however i wanted to point it out. 

i like that the game shows you where you have to go, but at the same time not showing the whole map, it makes you explore stuff more, but ofc you also explore to get more materials. The enemies are somewhat easy, i'm taking them down easily with the beginner laser, which i haven't been upgrading, all i have is a lifesteal upgrade on my robot, and one more thing which i forgot what was, so i'm still early on in the game. the robots usually have level 1-2 weapons on them when they die, and even though i have picked up two of those level 2 weapons, i don't use em much, mostly due to low ammo, and for some reason you can't reload weapons in this game, but instead swap em with new ones, and scrap them for materials... i guess it's fine but i'd like more upgradability with a weapon maybe.

If you love immersing yourself in another planet’s environment, Stormland is an absolute winner. The developers really seem to have delighted in creating a lush and organic world in which to embed their technology based story. The otherworldly plant life alone is worth the price of admission. Reminiscent of Star Trek the Original Series and No Man’s Sky alike. 

Voice acting is superb and heartfelt. Some of the robot characters gestures and personalities are really endearing, which provides some welcome relief from the devoid of human life techno-sphere. 

If you find yourself generally overwhelmed by the frenetic pace and violence of shooters, you’ll be eased into the shooter aspect of this game. The first hour or so is mostly exploration and acclimation into the story and world of Stormland. By the time combat ensues, its exciting but isn’t overwhelming. I’m about two hours into the game and can see the combat aspect ramping up. Still it’s a comfortable and intriguing pace. 

Absolutely recommended. Alongside Red Matter, Stormland is the most convincingly immersive VR experience to date. Highly recommended! Jump in there!

review_title: A masterpiece, but not without flaw
one_reviews_text:
While this is an incredible game, there are a few things I would like to change/add to the game

1: Riggs and my onboard AI should no longer tell me when I have a lot of alloy/Aeon buds because thanks to the palm-mounted objective menu, I can look at my alloy/Aeon stash whenever I want. 

2: I propose a new upgrade for the mod-station that allows the player to replace their dominant arm as well as their auxiliary arm (For example, one could have a maser arm on their left, and an static electricity arm on their right)

3: All weapon schematics lost after Terminus should be partially refunded as alloy, similar to how skills are refunded as growth.

4: When I am nearing the Spire Cell strongholds, a variety of glitches happen. For example, I can't hear the sounds or feel the vibration in my controllers when I grab an object or climb a wall, or the exact opposite: The controller aggressively vibrates in my hand for no apparent reason. Also, is the lightning on the central, square pillar really necessary? I think it looks cool with just the pulsating, purple glowing strips, and my computer can hardly handle it as is.

5: That's another thing. I am playing this game on an ASUS computer with intel Core i7 and a Nvidia Geforce GTX game card, yet the game starts to stutter and lag at the most crucial moments despite having the lowest settings, leaving me vulnerable to my opponent's attacks. I'd rather be directly killed by the Tempest's firepower and military might than be killed by lag. It is dishonorable. Other than that, this game is amazing, and mostly succeeds at being the biggest open-world VR game at the time of writing this review!

This was a day one purchase for me after having followed the hype leading up to release. The graphics and immersion are just as good as the trailers implied, which is fantastic. 

The disappointment for me set in once I got through the “tutorial” and started getting thrown into battle. So here’s my beef:

1.) Holstering Weapons. I can’t do this naturally without looking like any other shooter in VR. The guns are always glitching out and I have to look down in the heat of battle to make sure I’m not throwing my guns away. Worse yet, the guns are basically two handed and the trigger finger defaults to whichever hand grabs it first. So that gun in your left holster? Better awkwardly grab it with your right hand or you’ll be stuck firing it with your left finger. These issues alone just about ruin the game for me, but sadly it gets worse. 

2.) Ammo feels scarce. Perhaps some people enjoy having to constantly conserve ammo, but I’m not one of them. As far as I can tell, you can only get ammo by killing enemies and ripping apart their guns to get a few bullets or finding a “workbench” that I can only seem to find at the reset point after I’ve just died, and even then, you have to purchase the refill.

3.) Climbing with your hands is a cool idea, but the execution in this game is so bad. Especially if you’ve played Lone Echo, you know how this should work and feel, but sadly Stormland managed to make this extremely glitchy, inconsistent, and frustrating. Your hand won’t “grip” like half of the time, and the times they do, you can’t consistently fling yourself upward like you’re supposed to be able to do. When it works it’s actually really cool, but it fails so often that I’m left flinging my arms downward like an idiot over and over until I can get it to work. I’m not sure how they messed this up so bad. It’s flawless in a game like lone echo / echo combat. 

4.) You can’t control save points, and when you die (because you can’t find ammo anywhere) you get reset back incredibly far back onto some island and lose tons of progress or ground covered. This one was the final straw for me, because I don’t have hours and hours to play VR. Once I released how severe the setbacks were upon death, I realized I can’t even get into the game much at all. I can’t even get a refund at this point, but I wish I could.
How about multiple save points in 2020?

review_title: The new gold standard for VR movement
one_reviews_text:
I just finished my first full cycle in the game.

This game is pretty incredible! While it is a little rough around the edges (little bugs here and there, controls can sometimes be a bit quirky with specific functions), the core gameplay itself is tons of fun. The best mechanic is how easily and freely you can move around--hovering, climbing, gliding, slipstream mechanics are amazing. The best part is that this movement ties strongly into gameplay; moving around intelligently can get you a strong tactical advantage in fights. Even slipstreaming onto the right part of a stronghold can get you a good leg up when attempting that content. The fact that you can improve and change so much with your locomotion too over time is incredible, too.

As of now, the game is pretty easy--the campaign/tutorial was probably harder than the final area of the first full cycle. I assume future cycles will change and improve this over time, given dev commentary on the game.

Insomniac's latest and probably final Oculus title (since they were recently acquired by SONY), took me 22 hours to go through the campaign (7 hrs) and 2 cycles of terminus (escalation level 2).  Going through the cycled world a 3rd time grants you the secret alternate ending (which I haven't done yet and will probably add another 3-4 hrs). Thus, Stormland easily delivers 20+ hours of gameplay.

Stormland has amazing next generation traversal mechanics (flying, slipstreaming, climbing, gliding). Playing using the traversal mechanics alone can be addicting; combine it with exploring islands (the environments look amazing!!), mining alloy, harvesting fruit, and finding hidden collectables, and you have your own mini-game within Stormland.

Combat: the gunplay is average at best. The guns are very cool to look at and fun to use, but the gun upgrades only grant additional ammo capacity (and slightly higher dmg), and the enemy AI isn't the best/smart enough to fight against.  In the end, combat ends up becoming an easy chore when combined with character skill unlocks.

When Stormland was premiered at E3 2018, Oculus promised us a title with deep gameplay and next-generation mechanics.  Stormland does deliever on the next gen mechanics, but it falls short on the deep gameplay we all had hoped for.  If the campaign was longer (10+ hrs), then I think it would have been better received.  

Overall, Stormland features shallow repetitive gameplay, but the 'literally amazing' traversal mechanics help mitigate it's shortcomings. Stormland is still a worthy title that will deliver 20+ hrs of fun.

So I wrote out waaaaaaay too much not realizing there's a limit on how many words I can type SOOOOOO I'll leave it to this: 

Movement: 10/10, climbing, gliding, incredibly fast sprinting, and the slipstream system (basically just gliding around at mach 7 using your arms to steer), all add make for a super smooth and intuitive movement system.

Gunplay: Kinda lackluster weaponry so far (I have unlocked an SMG, shotgun, and Carbine rifle) HOWEVER the mechanics behind them are phenomenal. You can hold a gun with one hand for a basic shot, or hold it with two for a cool animation that makes your gun look extra pretty and get some upgrades (SMG gets more accurate and faster fire rate, shotgun does a good deal more damage, and Rifle gets a neat lil scope and bonus damage). There is no reloading, when you're out of ammo you strip the weapon for parts and find another one.

Story: Amazing so far. Starts super mysterious, and the atmosphere is very impressive. Characters all actually feel real and in depth, voice acting is phenomenal, and character progression actually feels fleshed out. The upgrade system is simply collect resources by smashing boxes and ore deposits, then spend them on better guns, or fabricating items to use. You can also smash plants and stuff later to upgrade your flower heart (its a thing) to make your android do more cool stuff, like turning scrapped weapons into grenades, double jump, better shield, etc. I also love that you can rip your arm off and replace it with a better one. Just sayin'.

All in all, it's amazing, and my review really can't do it justice. The weapons feel a little sluggish but it has amazing exploration, character progression, and atmosphere to boot. For $40, buy it, buy it now. You'll thank me later. Or not. Just make sure to thank yourself ;)

review_title: Great game, few issues that need fixing
one_reviews_text: This is a great game.  It's clear that this was designed from the ground up with VR in mind.  The interactivity is very well done.  Especially small details like grabbing and tearing apart enemy guns with both hands to recover material and ammo from them.  Once you're all decked out with all your gear / modules you really have an ironman type feeling while playing, it's fantastic.  The only things keeping me from giving this game 5 stars are: 1. It lacks multiple save slots.  This is 2019, how are game developers still making this mistake?  Most households only have 1 VR headset.  It's conceivable that multiple people are going to want to play the same VR game on the same computer.  You should offer at least 4 individual save slots.  2. The arm animations are not great.  The hand movement is nice and smooth but then you look over at the arms and often times they are jittering all over the place.  It's very immersion breaking.  I looked for an option to turn off the arm rendering and just have the hands like you can do in many other VR titles but alas there is no such option.  Either fix the arm animations to smooth them out (I've seen other games do this much better) or add the option to turn off the rendering of your body and only render the hands.  3. Get rid of the controller rumble and display of ammo summary when putting your hands on your sides where you guns are.  It's annoying resting your hands there (which is the natural place to have hands at rest while walking) and having that constant intermittent buzzing and ammo displays coming and going.  It's very immersion breaking and not useful at all.  If I want to know how much ammo my guns have I just have to grab them and look.  I also don't need controller vibration to tell me when my hands are over them, I know exactly where they are.  An option to turn both those things off would be fantastic.  Other than those 3 annoyances this is a great game and easily in my top 3 list for VR (out of the 30+ I've tried)

What a great looking and feeling game. I mean, if I have a choice of playing this game or watching the Dolphins when they're down by 21, it's no contest. Reading some of the reviews, some folks had issues but I found a way around them. The thing I love about this game is the strategy - if you're smart with your resources you can really get stuff done. And the game allows you to do that - find a bunch of enemies, get some intel on their location/numbers, and you can do whatever you want to shoot them down. Personally, I love the sniper position. I get good medium-long range rifles and shoot them from a high position. If you don't get the red dot on the target, try switching eyes. Careful with which guns you have holstered before you leave an area - sometimes the game switches guns by accident. Intro: I'm a VR Dev and also a VR fanatic since the early days of VR.  I am not one to pretend the technology is not still in development, we have a far way to come, that being said -- some amazing things are happening.

Stormland - The Good:
The game has an outstanding feel to it.  Everything from the speedy racing through the Stormland with a very fluid and fun movement system and climbing system to the combat mechanics. I will spare the long review but I will say the inventory and menu system is very well done and I honestly have not experienced anything this good since "Lone Echo".

Combat also feels rather good, albeit not perfect.  Gun selections and upgrade including the ability upgrade tree for your character are all well played out and actually a first for VR -- most VR games do not even touch on character progression.

Story - Reasonable length, well narrated and well played out.  It leaves enough to question as to where you wish to proceed but it's not so much that it is boring.  The "ending" is not really an ending as you begin another ongoing adventure.  Stormland seemingly aims to bring an evolving world (MMO style) into VR.  There are other features which allow multiplayer aspects although I have not fully explored them.  In a sense that element and the world almost reminds me of "Destiny 2" style in terms of online play.

The Bad - Stormland:
There are few bad things to say.  I will mention that the controls are ocasionally glitchy and throughout the "main campaign" I had maybe 2 or 3 moments where I was annoyed because of a quick control glitch.  It was nothing serious but it's a factor.  In addition, the input sometimes seems "laggy", your arms or hands are just a few milliseconds behind in the game and you can notice it, only breifly.  

Combat does feel great however at times it almost feels flat or clunky.  Overall these cons are minor and I highly recommend this game to FPS fans and adventure fans alike.

review_title: How to fix pre-ordered but no download
one_reviews_text:
If your game says 'Pre-ordered' but there is no download option available: I was able to do this and it is now downloading for me: 

1. Go to Oculus Support Website and Log in. 
2. Go to Your Orders and find Stormland Order
3. IF IT STATES THAT THE PREORDER FAILED: Cancel the pre-order on Stormland.
4. Restart your Oculus App 
5. Go to Oculus Store on App, you will see that its available again to buy. 
6. Buy like normal 
7. Proceed to download.

EDIT: I don't know if this method works for those who actually had their pre-order charged, or if it cancels the pre-order exclusives.  If you just want to play the game and it states 'Pre-Order failed' on Oculus Support orders, the above will work.

review_title: Solid UI, great story, beautiful worlds
one_reviews_text:
First things first, the user interface and interaction system is dialed in and one of the nicer I've used in a VR title that didn't feel like it was flat-panel best practices cobbled into a VR interface.

The HUD is one of the best I've seen, all important information is just in the perephry of your vision, and the ability to enable/disable it with a fingertap to temple gesture is a good use of VR UI as opposed to a button binding.

The worlds are beatufully detailed, and if you like exploring and finding hidden items there is a lot to do.  The climing mechanic takes a minute to get used to, but once you become accustomed to it you can easily scale most obstacles with a single hand.

There are only a few things I need in a VR experience to have a good time, tell me a story, present me with characters I can become emotionally invested in, give me beatiful worlds to explore, and present me with challenges.  Stormland does all this well.

In my previous review I complained about the shortness of the game and gave it three stars.  After playing more with Stormland I realized that this title deserves 5 stars (maybe more).  Is it a perfect AAA game?  No. I still regret that the developers have not devoted more resources to expand the story and add scenarios.  And I'm disappointed that Insomniac Games will now work exclusively for Sony and won't even be able to update the contents, perhaps releasing new DLCs.  BUT: the graphics are fantastic.  The worlds are rich in details, vegetation, different and varied textures.  The game mechanics exploit VR in a sublime way.  Every gesture is fluid and natural.  Even the most magical actions can be performed naturally.  The content is sufficiently mixed and not boring.  In practice, the elements that constitute Stormland are repeated and are not so many, taken individually.  But they are used wisely in order to prolong interest and challenge.  Enemies gradually become more intelligent and difficult to destroy.  The various islands slightly change, always with new small details that make them interesting to explore.  For now, this game is the best that VR can offer, along with Asgard's Wrath which is superior in variety and complexity.  Since the genre is the same, I want to mention here Seeking Dawn.  It was less publicized, less engaging but another good title of the same kind.  I gave him 5 stars some time ago.  Stormland therefore deserves 6 and Asgard's Wrath 7.

Just finished the main story line.  Outstanding AAA game!

The game was designed with VR in mind.  Interacting with the environment feels completely natural.  Most of the world is manipulated and interacted with by using your hands.  Anywhere a menu is involved is very well integrated and, again, is manipulated with your hands rather than your controller toggle.  Well done there.

Once the storyline is done, the whole game shuffles around weekly to give a large replayability factor. 

I've experienced very few glitches/bugs.  Fell inside a mountain and couldn't get back out and there have been a few times an elevator button glitched out and wouldn't work.  Also, at the end of the main story line, a door that was supposed to unlock didn't.  But a reload  sorted things out with very little loss in progress.
If Insomniac address some of these minor glitches in their first post-release patch, the game will be dang near perfect in my opinion.

Climbing occasionally has some invisible walls, which aren't super well telegraphed, but that's not a deal breaker in the least. Gliding especially feels good, and combat is interesting so far. The versatility of weaponry is so so, so far. It's nice that each weapon has a different functionality when used with two hands, although the differences can be minimal depending on the weapon. One of the few downsides is weapon handling. Weapons can feel a bit floaty, and it lacks the snappiness of an Arizona Sunshine, for instance. This extends to interacting with certain objects as well.
